titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Helen Milliken Papers, 1965-1982

Finding aid prepared by:
Avra Michelson

did.abstract: Civic leader, wife of Michigan governor William Milliken; topical files relating to Artrain, the Michigan Council for the Arts, the International Women's Year, Youth for Understanding, women's rights issues, notably the Equal Rights Amendment, and environmental protection issues; correspondence files; appearance files; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Helen W. Milliken (donor no. 6863), and was accessioned through her administrative assistant, Mrs. Mary Browder, and Mrs. Phyllis Monroe, her secretary.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Mrs. Milliken transferred her copyright in her papers to the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Helen W. Milliken Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Helen Wallbank Milliken, a native of Denver, Colorado, was educated at the Kent School for Girls and Smith College (B.A., 1945). After the end of the war, she married William Milliken, who she had met earlier in Denver.
In 1946, following his graduation from Yale, the Millikens settled in Traverse City, the home of William Milliken and the location of the family-owned Milliken Department Store.

Helen Milliken's interest in and involvement with Michigan politics paralleled her husband's rise within state government: his election to the State Senate in 1960, and his terms as Lieutenant Governor (1965-1969), and Governor (1969-1983).

As wife of the Governor, Helen Milliken was called upon to perform as Michigan First lady. In addition to certain ceremonial duties, however, she assumed other responsibilities and made significant contributions in the areas of the arts, environmental protection, and women's rights. She was an avid supporter of the Michigan Council for the Arts and served (since 1971) as honorary chairperson of Artrain, a traveling cultural exhibit.

Equally concerned about environmental protection, Helen Milliken spoke out on a number of issues--the control of billboard advertising, the prohibition of throw away bottles, and the restriction of oil drilling in the Pigeon River State Forest.

But without question, Helen Milliken was most outspoken on women's rights issues. She was a vigorous advocate of the Equal Rights Amendment, and wrote and spoke frequently on its behalf. In 1975, she made a tour with American Women for International Understanding to the People's Republic of China. And in 1977, she worked as convenor of the Michigan organization and delegate to the International Women's Year Conference in Houston. Beginning in 1978, she also served as co-chairperson of ERAmerica.

Throughout William Milliken's tenure as governor, Helen Milliken served in numerous organizations reflecting the variety of her own interests. Included were the Michigan Environmental Association, the Michigan Nature Association, the Society of Architects, the League of Women Voters, the Business and Professional Women's Club, the Federation for American Immigration Reform, Zero Population Growth, and the Federated Garden Club of Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The Helen Milliken papers total 18.4 linear feet of correspondence, organizational records, printed material, and photographs largely from the period 1969-1982 (though there are some items dating back to 1965). The collection consists of four principal series: Topical Files, Correspondence, Appearances, and Photographs. Preceding these is a file of Biographical Material.

The Topical Files (arranged alphabetically) consist of correspondence, organizational records, printed material, and clippings on subjects reflecting Helen Milliken's interest in the arts, environmental protection, and women's rights. The principal subjects within this series concern Artrain, International Women's Year, the Michigan Council for the Arts, and Youth for Understanding. Other subjects (less heavily documented) include billboard control, the Equal Rights Amendment, the Pigeon River State Forest controversy, the Project on Equal Education Rights, and the Special Commission on Art in State Buildings. The remaining files are uneven in content. Some contain significant correspondence or policy-related records; others include only perfunctory materials.

The papers relating to Artrain are the most voluminous set of files within the Topical Files series. Totaling approximately 4 linear feet, the Artrain files includes background material, records of meetings, planning reports, fund raising materials, scattered memoranda and periodicals, and correspondence (one group arranged chronologically, another alphabetically). There are also files relating to the tours made by the Artrain, scrapbooks of clippings, and promotional audio-tapes.

scopecontent.p: The International Women's Year set of files within the Topical Files series includes ca. 6 inches of papers relating to the state planning conference for the Houston conference, the Michigan delegation's activities at the conference, and post-conference activities. Included are planning notes and handouts, transcripts, resolutions, correspondence, a brief diary, and an article composed by Helen Milliken.

scopecontent.p: There is approximately 1 linear foot of papers relating to the development and goals of the Michigan Council for the Arts, and to the meetings of the Executive Committee, the Council, the Environmental Arts Committee, and various other bodies. The activities of the Executive Committee and the Council are so closely intertwined that the researcher should consult both if interested in one. And as Artrain once had an institutional relationship with the Michigan Council for the Arts, the researcher should be alerted to Artrain material here, especially in the 1970 Council Meeting folder.

scopecontent.p: The Youth for Understanding files within the Topical Files series total ca. 1 linear foot of historical items, agenda, minutes, resolutions, correspondence, memoranda, grants, and reports and proposals documenting the activities of this international teenage exchange program.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence covers the period 1969-1982 and measures ca. 1.5 linear feet of files. The correspondence has been arranged chronologically. As items are often attached, they have been filed chronologically by the date of the top letter. The Correspondence Files supplements other correspondence found throughout the Topical Files and the Appearances Files. Effort was made, however, to bring together within the Topical Files correspondence relating to Artrain, International Women's Year, the Michigan Council for the Arts, and Youth for Understanding.
Helen Milliken's Appearance Files are arranged chronologically and include correspondence, administrative request forms, printed materials, clippings, and miscellanea.

The Photographs series is arranged by topic and is most extensive for images on the Artrain. In addition, there are photographs of William Milliken and political events that Helen Milliken attended. Also of note is a folder of photographs relating to trips to China and to Russia.
